stem: The nurse is reviewing the patient's electronic health record (EHR). Based on the assessment data, which intervention is MOST important for the nurse to implement?

itemContext.sbar: S: Jameson Walker, 72-year-old male, admitted for altered mental status. History of hypertension, diabetes mellitus, and stage 3 chronic kidney disease (CKD). B: Found confused at home by family at 06:00. Last known normal was yesterday evening. Reports nausea. A: At 07:00, lethargic, oriented only to person. BP 170/95 mmHg, HR 98 bpm, RR 24, SpO2 94% on room air. Temp 37.2°C. EKG shows peaked T waves. Meds: Lisinopril, Metformin, Aspirin. Urine output scant (30mL) in last 2 hours. Labs pending. Vitals reviewed. Radiology unavailable. MAR reflects current meds. A: Possible hyperkalemia and acute kidney injury (AKI) superimposed on CKD, exacerbating confusion. R: STAT BMP and EKG ordered. Nephrology notified. Consider sodium polystyrene sulfonate. Continuous cardiac monitoring. Reassess mental status frequently. Monitor cardiac rhythm closely.

tabs.title: SBAR
tabs.content: S: Jameson Walker, 72-year-old male, admitted for altered mental status. History of hypertension, diabetes mellitus, and stage 3 chronic kidney disease (CKD). B: Found confused at home by family at 06:00. Last known normal was yesterday evening. Reports nausea. A: At 07:00, lethargic, oriented only to person. BP 170/95 mmHg, HR 98 bpm, RR 24, SpO2 94% on room air. Temp 37.2°C. EKG shows peaked T waves. Meds: Lisinopril, Metformin, Aspirin. Urine output scant (30mL) in last 2 hours. Labs pending. Vitals reviewed. Radiology unavailable. MAR reflects current meds. A: Possible hyperkalemia and acute kidney injury (AKI) superimposed on CKD, exacerbating confusion. R: STAT BMP and EKG ordered. Nephrology notified. Consider sodium polystyrene sulfonate. Continuous cardiac monitoring. Reassess mental status frequently. Monitor cardiac rhythm closely.

tabs.title: Labs
tabs.content:
LabValueReference Range
Sodium140 mEq/L135-145 mEq/L
Potassium6.8 mEq/L3.5-5.0 mEq/L
Chloride102 mEq/L95-105 mEq/L
BUN60 mg/dL8-20 mg/dL
Creatinine3.5 mg/dL0.6-1.2 mg/dL
Glucose180 mg/dL70-110 mg/dL
eGFR28 mL/min/1.73 m2>60 mL/min/1.73 m2

topicTags: Renal: AKI vs CKD & Electrolyte Emergencies

rationale.correct:
Administering sodium polystyrene sulfonate is the most important intervention due to the patient's potassium level of 6.8 mEq/L, indicating hyperkalemia. Hyperkalemia can lead to life-threatening cardiac arrhythmias, supported by peaked T waves on the EKG. Sodium polystyrene sulfonate lowers potassium by exchanging sodium for potassium ions in the intestine, promoting excretion in the stool. Given the severity, addressing hyperkalemia takes priority. 

clinicalPearl: Monitor for hypokalemia and sodium retention as potential side effects of sodium polystyrene sulfonate.
rationale.incorrect:
While monitoring urine output is important in patients with AKI and CKD, it is not the immediate priority given the hyperkalemia. Addressing the electrolyte imbalance is critical to prevent cardiac complications.

Elevating the head of the bed may improve oxygenation and comfort, but it does not address the life-threatening hyperkalemia. The SpO2 is 94% on room air, indicating adequate oxygenation currently.

Notifying the provider about the change in mental status is important, but this has already been done per the SBAR. The nurse should independently act on the critical lab value (hyperkalemia) while awaiting further orders.
clinicalPearls: Peaked T waves on EKG are a classic sign of hyperkalemia.
Hyperkalemia can be a life-threatening complication of AKI and CKD.
Sodium polystyrene sulfonate can take several hours to have a noticeable effect on potassium levels.

questionTrap.trap: The question traps the test-taker into focusing on the AKI/CKD aspect and overlooking the immediate danger of hyperkalemia.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Carefully assess all available data (labs, vitals, and SBAR) to identify the most life-threatening condition requiring immediate intervention.

mnemonic.title: MURDER
mnemonic.expansion: M: Muscle weakness, U: Urine (oliguria/anuria), R: Respiratory distress, D: Decreased cardiac contractility, E: EKG changes (peaked T waves), R: Reflexes (hyperreflexia or areflexia)

options.body: Elevate the head of the bed to 30 degrees.
Notify the provider about the change in mental status.
